title: Plural formation
explanation: Armenian forms the plural by attaching suffixes to the end of the noun. According to a grammar resource, monosyllabic nouns add **-er** while polysyllabic nouns add **-ner**【601007166987671†L52-L61】. This is different from English where plural formation often involves adding **-s** or **-es**.

title: Forming adverbs
explanation: Many Armenian adverbs are formed by adding the particle **-որեն** (‑oren) to adjectives【601007166987671†L65-L77】. Some adverbs are native words without this ending, such as **hima** (now), **irakan** (really) and **shutov** (quickly).

title: Articles and definiteness
explanation: Unlike English, Armenian attaches its definite article to the end of the noun. There are two forms of the definite article: **‑ը / ‑ն** (pronounced roughly as *‑e* and *‑n*) depending on the final sound of the noun【601007166987671†L100-L117】. Armenian has no indefinite article; indefiniteness is indicated by context or by using the numeral **մեկ** (mek). By contrast, Persian marks indefiniteness with the suffix **ی** (‑i) or by adding words like **yek** or **chand**, and has no definite article【15005834654091†L204-L227】.

title: Present, past and future tenses
explanation: Armenian verbs form tenses by combining the verb stem with particles rather than changing endings. For the present tense the verb stem is followed by particles **եմ, ես, է, ենք, եք, են** corresponding to the subject. For example, **Yes kardum em** (I read), **Du kardum es** (you read), **Na kardum e** (he/she reads)【601007166987671†L124-L141】. In the past tense the particle **էի / էիր / էր / էինք / էիք / էին** is used【601007166987671†L147-L185】, and in the future tense **կ** is prefixed before the particles (e.g., **Yes k kardam**, I will read).

title: Negation
explanation: Negation in Armenian is formed by adding the particle **չ** (ch) before the verb particle. In the third person singular and plural the final vowel of the particle changes to **ի**【601007166987671†L199-L213】. This contrasts with English, which typically inserts **not** after an auxiliary.

title: Questions and word order
explanation: Armenian questions generally use the same word order as statements; the interrogative is indicated by intonation or punctuation (a question mark) rather than by inversion or auxiliary verbs【601007166987671†L189-L195】. This is similar to Persian and unlike English where auxiliary verbs are moved to the start of the sentence.

title: Personal pronouns
explanation: The basic Armenian personal pronouns are **ես** (yes – I), **դու** (du – you singular), **նա** (na – he/she), **մենք** (menk – we), **դուք** (duk – you plural) and **նրանք** (nrank – they)【601007166987671†L229-L236】. These pronouns precede the verb, unlike Persian which often omits subject pronouns because the verb endings indicate the subject.
